name: Mount Marathon Race
hook: Up-and-down madness on Seward’s steep, scree-choked mountain.
description: A Fourth of July tradition since 1915, racers charge 3,000 vertical feet from downtown Seward straight up Mount Marathon and descend on loose scree and gullies back to town. The course is short but brutally steep, with real hazards and huge crowds lining the streets.
cost: Lottery entry; adult fees published annually
lodging: Hotels and vacation rentals in Seward; book early for the holiday week. Limited camping nearby.

name: Pinhoti 100
hook: Point‑to‑point across Alabama’s Pinhoti Trail with 14,000+ feet of climb.
description: A Southeastern classic starting near Pine Glen Campground and finishing in Sylacauga. Technical singletrack, creek crossings, and fall colors headline the route.
cost: Standard entry; details on organizer site
lodging: Motels in Anniston/Heflin and Sylacauga; crewed race with aid stations.

name: XTERRA Appalachian Trail Fest
hook: Rocky singletrack, creek splashes, and festival vibes at Oak Mountain.
description: XTERRA’s trail fest at Oak Mountain State Park offers 35K and 15K options with scrambles, roots, and classic Alabama forest. A family hike and on-site festival round out a full day at one of the Southeast’s best trail systems.
cost: Registration via UltraSignup; fees vary by distance
lodging: Cabins/camping inside Oak Mountain; hotels in Pelham/Hoover nearby.

name: Hogeye Marathon & Relays
hook: Marathon and relays winding through Springdale’s scenic forest trails.
description: Held in Springdale’s downtown and surrounding trail system, the Hogeye Marathon is a club-run favorite featuring a forested half-marathon, marathon, and relay options all on rugged terrain north of the Arkansas Ozarks.
venue: Downtown Springdale → Trails northwest of city
lodging: Hotels in Springdale and Fayetteville; limited camping at nearby state parks.

name: Across the Years
hook: Fixed-time events spanning 6-day, 72/48/24-hour, and ultra distances across New Year’s week.
description: Held at the Peoria Sports Complex, this multi-day ultra festival lets runners choose fixed-time or distance challenges—including 6-Day, 72/48/24-hour options, 100K, 100-mile and more—wrapping New Year’s with endurance and community.
cost: Standard distance-based entry; see official site for 2025 pricing
lodging: Hotels near the sports complex book fast for holiday-heavy event; limited campground on site.

name: Black Canyon Ultras
hook: Fast desert singletrack on the Black Canyon Trail—golden-ticket stakes.
description: Point-to-point 100K and 50K over Sonoran Desert singletrack with big views and creek crossings. The 100K is a Western States qualifier and often a Golden Ticket race, drawing deep competition and a lively scene from Mayer to New River.
cost: Online registration tiers; UltraSignup fees apply
venue: Mayer High School (start) → Emery Henderson Trailhead (finish)
lodging: Hotels along I-17 corridor (Cordes Lakes, Black Canyon City, Phoenix); limited camping at nearby trailheads.

name: Cocodona 250
hook: A 250-mile traverse linking desert, canyons, wine country, and pines to Flagstaff.
description: Aravaipa’s multi-day epic stitches the Black Canyon, Bradshaw Mountains, Prescott, Jerome, Sedona and the AZ Trail into one massive point-to-point. Crewed aid, long remote sections, and relentless vert make this a bucket-list sufferfest.
cost: Tiered entry pricing; UltraSignup processing fees apply
lodging: Hotels and rentals in Crown King, Prescott, Cottonwood/Sedona, and Flagstaff; book early.

name: Javelina Jundred
hook: Costumed desert loops and roaring aid stations at the original Jalloween ultra.
description: Hosted at McDowell Mountain Regional Park, runners tackle looped courses on the Pemberton Trail under hot days and cool nights. The 100-mile is a WSER qualifier and regular Golden Ticket race, blending party atmosphere with elite fields.
cost: Waitlist/registration via official site; fees vary by distance
lodging: Camping in the park (reserve early); hotels in Fountain Hills/Scottsdale.

name: Tucson Marathon & 50K
hook: Marathon and 50K through desert landscapes concluding at Biosphere 2.
description: Aravaipa Running’s winter race includes marathon, 50K, half-marathon, and relay starting at Biosphere 2. Expect desert air, varied terrain, and views of the iconic science facility near Tucson.
lodging: Hotels in Tucson; campgrounds in Catalina State Park;

name: Adventure Van Expo – Lake Tahoe
hook: Custom vans, builders, demos, and van‑life culture at Tahoe.
description: One of the series’ flagship shows with builders, gear brands, van tours, talks, and community meetups. Family‑friendly with camping options at area campgrounds.
cost: Spectator tickets; some activities free
venue: South Lake Tahoe venue (varies by year)
lodging: Hotels and campgrounds around South Lake Tahoe; summer weekends book early.

name: Angeles Crest 100
hook: High‑heat, high‑climb classic across the San Gabriel Mountains.
description: A rugged 100‑mile point‑to‑point from Wrightwood to Altadena with major climbs, heat exposure, and tight cutoffs. An iconic test piece of California mountain ultrarunning.
cost: Lottery/entry via UltraSignup; fees vary annually
lodging: Limited lodging in Wrightwood; ample options in Pasadena/Altadena.

name: Badwater 135
hook: 135 miles from below sea level to the High Sierra in desert heat.
description: AdventureCORPS’ invitational crosses Death Valley in peak summer, climbing three ranges en route to Whitney Portal. Strict crew rules, extreme heat management, and agency permits make it one of the world’s hardest ultras.
cost: Application-based entry; fees announced annually
lodging: Lodging in Stovepipe Wells, Furnace Creek, and Lone Pine; reserve far in advance.

name: Broken Arrow Skyrace
hook: Granite slabs, ladders, and high-altitude snowfields at Palisades Tahoe.
description: A weekend of mountain races from 11K to 46K plus the Iron Face Challenge. Spectators ride lifts to cheer sections near the ridgelines; weather can add snow and drama to the course.
cost: Tiered entry; prices vary by distance
lodging: Resort lodging at Palisades Tahoe; hotels/rentals in Olympic Valley and Truckee.

name: California River Quest
hook: 25–100 mile Sacramento River paddle with fast current and checkpoints.
description: A Sacramento River marathon/ultramarathon paddle offering multiple distances from Redding to Chico. Features set checkpoints, safety requirements, and a community finish celebration.
cost: Tiered entry fees by distance and craft
lodging: Hotels and RV parks in Redding/Chico; shuttles and logistics provided.

name: Catalina Channel Crossing – US Outrigger Championships
hook: Classic OC6 channel crossing between Newport and Catalina Island.
description: Separate women’s and men’s championships traverse the Catalina Channel in open ocean conditions. Hosted by the Southern California Outrigger Racing Association.
cost: Team entry; escort boat required
lodging: Hotels in Newport Beach and on Catalina; boat logistics essential.

name: Santa Cruz Paddlefest
hook: Steamer Lane surf‑kayak and SUP contest with clinics and community events.
description: A surf‑paddle festival at Santa Cruz’s famed Steamer Lane, often pairing competitions with clinics and community gatherings. Event scope can vary year to year.
cost: Entry fee for competitors; spectating free
lodging: Hotels and rentals around West Cliff Drive and downtown.

name: Western States 100
hook: Granite high country to hot canyons—trail running’s original 100-miler.
description: From Olympic Valley to the Placer High track in Auburn, runners face snow, canyons, and heat. Entry is via qualification and lottery; the event anchors North American ultrarunning history.
cost: Lottery entry; fee announced annually
lodging: Hotels in Olympic Valley and Auburn; book early for race week.

name: Colorado Springs Labor Day Lift Off
hook: Mass balloon lift-offs and evening glows with a Front Range backdrop.
description: A Colorado Springs Labor Day tradition with morning mass ascensions at Memorial Park, evening balloon glows, live music, and family activities with Pikes Peak on the skyline.
cost: Spectator events free; paid add-ons available
lodging: Hotels throughout Colorado Springs; reserve early for the holiday weekend.

name: Desert RATS Trail Running Festival
hook: High-desert singletrack and redrock vistas over a three-day race weekend.
description: A multi-distance festival on Fruita’s Kokopelli-area trails with 10K, 21K, 50K, and 100K options. Courses showcase slickrock, canyon views, and classic desert singletrack along the Colorado River corridor.
lodging: Hotels in Fruita and Grand Junction; BLM and state park campgrounds along the river corridors.

name: GoPro Mountain Games
hook: Adventure sports, concerts, art, and community take over Vail for four epic days.
description: Vail’s multi-sport festival mixes trail running, climbing, whitewater, biking, fishing, yoga, and live music with family-friendly exhibits and vendor zones across four days in June.
lodging: Hotels and condos in Vail; book early for summer events.

name: Hardrock Hundred Mile Endurance Run
hook: 100 brutal miles above tree line over passes and scree in the San Juans.
description: An alpine circuit through Colorado’s San Juan Mountains with sustained high elevation, lingering snow, and steep, technical climbs. Entry is through a stringent qualification process and a weighted lottery.
cost: Lottery entry; fee announced annually
lodging: Motels, rentals, and campgrounds around Silverton/Ouray/Lake City; limited capacity during race week.

name: Imogene Pass Run
hook: Seventeen alpine miles over a 13,114′ pass between two mining towns.
description: A high-mountain point-to-point from Ouray to Telluride over Imogene Pass. Expect steep grades, thin air, and quickly changing weather with peak crowds at both historic endpoints.
cost: Registration opens July 1, 2025; details on official site
lodging: Hotels in Ouray/Telluride; limited camping on approach roads and nearby forest lands.

name: Leadville Trail 100 Run
hook: A high-altitude out-and-back with Hope Pass twice and thin-air miles.
description: Founded in 1983, the Leadville 100 sends runners from 10,000 feet up and over 12,600-foot Hope Pass—twice—before returning to town. Cutoffs, altitude, and weather swings define the challenge.
lodging: Hotels and rentals in Leadville; camping at Turquoise Lake and nearby national forest.

name: Ouray Ice Festival
hook: World-class ice climbing clinics, comps, and gear demos in the San Juan gorge.
description: Climbers gather in the Ouray Ice Park for clinics led by pros, vendor demos, and a signature competition in the Uncompahgre Gorge. Spectators can view action from park walkways and enjoy festival events around town.
cost: Spectating free; clinic/comp fees vary
lodging: Motels and lodges in Ouray/Ridgway; limited winter camping nearby.

name: Pikes Peak Marathon
hook: Up to 14,115′ and back on Barr Trail—America’s iconic summit race.
description: Starting in Manitou Springs, the marathon climbs the Barr Trail to the summit of Pikes Peak before descending back to town. Elevation, exposure, and fickle mountain weather make for a demanding day.
lodging: Hotels in Manitou Springs and Colorado Springs; book early for race weekend.

name: Run Rabbit Run 100
hook: High‑country singletrack over Mount Werner and Rabbit Ears.
description: A marquee mountain 100 with separate ‘Hares’ and ‘Tortoises’ fields, big prize money, and alpine terrain around Steamboat. A 50‑mile runs concurrently.
cost: Entry via UltraSignup; tiered fees
lodging: Resort lodging at the base area and in town; sell‑outs common.

name: Snowmass Balloon Festival
hook: Rocky Mountain launches with alpine backdrops and morning glows.
description: Balloon pilots launch from Snowmass Town Park with spectacular valley views. The weekend includes competitive tasks, glows, and community events.
cost: Free to attend
lodging: Resort lodging in Snowmass/Aspen; book early.

name: Green Swamp Sport Klassic
hook: Quest Air’s friendly hang‑gliding comp aimed at developing XC skills.
description: A week‑long aerotow hang‑gliding event at Quest Air Soaring Center emphasizing tasks for newer competitors and XC skill‑building, with mentoring and daily briefings.
cost: Pilot entry fee; spectators free
lodging: On‑site camping/RV; hotels in Clermont/Groveland.

name: Bad Apples PPG Fly‑In
hook: One of the biggest US paramotor fly‑ins at Hodges Field.
description: A large powered‑paragliding gathering with group flights, clinics, and vendor demos hosted at Hodges Field. Emphasis on safety briefings, morning/evening sessions, and community camping.
cost: Pilot registration fee; spectators typically free
lodging: On‑site camping common; additional hotels in Americus and nearby towns.

name: Georgia Death Race
hook: 70+ miles with huge vert across North Georgia’s rugged blue ridge.
description: A notorious point‑to‑point ultra linking Vogel State Park to Amicalola Falls State Park on steep, technical trails and forest roads. Entry is limited and often selected by lottery.
cost: Lottery/entry through organizer; fees announced annually
lodging: Cabins/camping at state parks; hotels in Blairsville/Dahlonega.

name: HURT 100
hook: Rooty, humid rainforest loops high above Honolulu’s city lights.
description: A five-loop, 100-mile course on technical singletrack in the rainforests above Honolulu, anchored by the Makiki, Mānoa and Nuʻuanu aid stations. Heat, humidity, slippery roots and steep climbing make finishes hard-earned. Runners start and finish at Hawaiʻi Nature Center in Makiki.
cost: Lottery entry; fee announced annually
lodging: Hotels throughout Honolulu; book early for race week.

name: Molokaʻi Hoe
hook: Historic open‑ocean outrigger canoe race across the Kaiwi Channel.
description: Elite men’s outrigger crews race from Molokaʻi to Oʻahu across the 26‑mile Kaiwi Channel. A premier long‑distance OC6 event with global participation.
cost: Team entry; escort boat required
lodging: Island lodging on Molokaʻi/Oʻahu; complex logistics for boats and crews.

name: Relay Iowa
hook: A 339-mile self-supported road relay across Iowa with team pit stops and camaraderie.
description: Relay teams of up to 12 run across Iowa in three days, switching legs while vans provide logistical support. Runners experience sunrise, sleep breaks, and community checkpoints on the longest continuous relay in the U.S.
lodging: End-of-day towns offer motels; many teams plan crew-stops and campground options.

name: Missouri American Water MR340
city: Kansas City, KS → St. Charles, MO
hook: 340 nonstop river miles—sun, current, checkpoints, and sheer grit.
description: The world’s longest nonstop river race starts at Kaw Point Park and follows the Missouri River to St. Charles. Solo and team craft manage heat, night paddling, and cutoff times across four days.
cost: Standard entry fees; see official site
venue: Start: Kaw Point Park; Finish: St. Charles riverfront
lodging: Hotels in Kansas City and St. Charles; many paddlers use road crews and riverside stops.

name: Rocktoberfest (Red River Gorge)
hook: Community climbing festival supporting access in Kentucky’s sandstone.
description: The Red River Gorge Climbers’ Coalition hosts clinics, comps, and evening events to raise funds for local climbing access and stewardship.
cost: Festival pass; clinic fees extra
lodging: Cabins and campgrounds around Slade and Natural Bridge State Resort Park.

name: JFK 50 Mile
hook: AT and C&O towpath to a fast historic 50-mile finish.
description: America’s oldest ultramarathon blends rocky Appalachian Trail miles with flat C&O Canal towpath before a road finish in Williamsport. The point-to-point route starts in Boonsboro and rewards smart pacing over mixed terrain.
cost: Tiered entry fees; see registration
lodging: Hotels in Hagerstown/Williamsport fill quickly around race weekend.

name: AuSable River Canoe Marathon
hook: Overnight 120‑mile canoe marathon down Michigan’s AuSable River.
description: Iconic nonstop canoe race from Grayling to Oscoda on the AuSable River. Teams paddle through the night with large crowds at the downtown start and finish on Lake Huron.
cost: Team entry fee; spectator viewing free
lodging: Motels and rentals in Grayling/Oscoda; book early for race weekend.

name: Great Lakes Paddle Challenge
hook: SUP and paddlecraft racing on open water off Kirk Park beach.
description: A Lake Michigan paddlesports race based at Ottawa County’s Kirk Park. Distances and formats vary by year with a beach start and Great Lakes conditions driving tactics.
cost: Standard entry fees via registration portal
address: 9791 N Lakeshore Dr, West Olive, MI 49460
lodging: Hotels in Holland/Grand Haven; summer weekends book quickly.

name: Michigan Ice Fest
hook: Pictured Rocks’ frozen pillars with pros, clinics, and demos.
description: One of North America’s largest ice festivals based in Munising with clinics along Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore, evening slideshows, and industry demos.
cost: Spectating free; clinic/demo passes ticketed
lodging: Winter lodging in Munising; limited camping options mid‑winter.

name: Superior 100 Mile Trail Race
hook: Rocky North Shore singletrack with relentless roots and climbs.
description: A point-to-point 100-miler along Minnesota’s Superior Hiking Trail. Runners traverse technical boreal forest singletrack from Gooseberry Falls toward a Lutsen finish, with big lake views and fickle fall weather.
cost: Standard entry; details on official site
lodging: Lodges and rentals at Lutsen; state park campgrounds along the course.

name: Great Forest Park Balloon Race
hook: Free balloon glow and race weekend in St. Louis’s Forest Park.
description: One of the nation’s longest‑running urban balloon events. Friday features the Balloon Glow; Saturday hosts the race from Emerson Central Fields with extensive family activities.
cost: Free admission; concessions and parking vary
lodging: Hotels in central and downtown St. Louis; heavy attendance on race weekend.

name: Bozeman Ice Festival
hook: Clinics, comps, and films celebrating Hyalite Canyon ice.
description: A long‑running ice‑climbing gathering with guided clinics, gear demos, competitions, and evening events that showcase Hyalite Canyon’s renowned routes.
cost: Spectating free; clinic/comp fees apply
lodging: Hotels in Bozeman; winter road access to Hyalite can be weather‑dependent.

name: Frosty Fifty Trail Races
hook: Fast lake-loop 50K on wide dirt around Salem Lake.
description: Twin City Track Club’s winter classic features a 50K, 25K, 12.5K and relay on a wide dirt loop circling Salem Lake. The 50K runs four 12.5K loops with post-race soup and local beer. Friday night includes a 5K under the lights.
cost: Standard entry fees; tiers published on registration page
lodging: Hotels in downtown Winston-Salem; short drive to the marina.

name: Green River Games
hook: Multi‑sport mountain festival with trail, bike, and whitewater events.
description: A weekend of rugged competitions and community events in the Green River Gorge area, often including trail runs, enduro MTB, and paddling races tied to the Saluda community.
cost: Event entries vary; spectating largely free
lodging: Cabins and campgrounds around Saluda/Hendersonville; limited on‑site options.

name: Green River Narrows Race
hook: Elite kayakers charge through Gorilla in the Southeast’s rowdiest creek race.
description: A steep-creek classic through the Green River Narrows’ Class V rapids near Saluda. The event draws the world’s best whitewater paddlers and big crowds along the gorge overlooks.
cost: Paddler entry fee announced annually; spectating free along public overlooks
lodging: Cabins and lodges around Saluda/Hendersonville; limited camping options nearby.

name: Albuquerque International Balloon Fiesta
hook: Mass ascensions fill New Mexico’s sky with hundreds of balloons.
description: The world‑famous fiesta stages dawn mass ascensions, night glows, and competition flights over Albuquerque. Events center around Balloon Fiesta Park with robust spectator access and amenities.
cost: Ticketed for spectators; pricing varies by session
lodging: Hotels across Albuquerque; RV sites at Balloon Fiesta Park sell out early.

name: Jemez Mountain Trail Runs
hook: Volcanic mesas and canyons above Los Alamos with stout climbs.
description: Multiple distances traverse Bandelier/Jemez terrain: punchy climbs, lava rock, and pine forest singletrack. A beloved New Mexico mountain classic.
cost: Entry via organizer; distances vary
lodging: Hotels and rentals in Los Alamos and nearby Española/Santa Fe.

name: Great Reno Balloon Race
hook: Dawn Patrol and mass ascension over Reno’s Rancho San Rafael Park.
description: A free, community balloon festival featuring the predawn Dawn Patrol followed by mass ascension and specialty shapes. Activities and viewing occur at Rancho San Rafael Regional Park.
cost: Free to attend; parking/shuttles may be paid
lodging: Hotels in Reno and nearby Sparks; book early for weekend dates.

name: Tahoe Rim Trail Endurance Runs
hook: High‑elevation 50K/100K/100M around Lake Tahoe’s east rim.
description: Courses start/finish at Western Nevada College and climb into the Carson Range on singletrack and dirt roads. Thin air, big views, and summer heat test runners.
cost: Entry via organizer; proceeds benefit local trail groups
lodging: Hotels in Carson City and South Lake Tahoe; midsummer pricing.

name: Adirondack Balloon Festival
hook: Sunrise launches and evening glows in New York’s Lake George region.
description: A multi‑day festival based at Floyd Bennett Memorial Airport and Crandall Park. Features morning mass ascensions, tethered rides, and a popular evening glow.
cost: Free admission; parking donations or fees at some venues
venue: Floyd Bennett Memorial Airport / Crandall Park
lodging: Hotels and rentals around Glens Falls/Lake George; peak fall demand.

name: General Clinton Canoe Regatta
hook: 70‑mile Susquehanna River canoe classic with park festival.
description: A storied marathon canoe race culminating at General Clinton Park with a community fair and multiple youth/adult classes. Logistics include portages and river reading.
cost: Entry fees by class; festival largely free
lodging: Motels and camping in Bainbridge/Oneonta; Cooperstown lodging near the start.

name: General Clinton Canoe Regatta
hook: 70‑mile canoe classic on the Susquehanna with festival events.
description: A storied marathon canoe race from Cooperstown to Bainbridge anchored by a community festival at General Clinton Park. Multiple classes and youth races run throughout the weekend.
cost: Entry fees by class; park parking/concessions available
lodging: Local motels and camping at/near the park.

name: Descend On Bend
hook: Huge van‑life gathering in Oregon’s high desert with camping and community.
description: A four‑day van‑life campout near La Pine with thousands of attendees, DIY rigs, workshops, vendors, and communal meals. The event has moved sites over the years but retains a late‑summer tradition in Central Oregon.
cost: Ticketed; prices vary by vehicle and pass
venue: Outback Station area (La Pine NF vicinity)
lodging: On‑site camping included with passes; additional campgrounds and rentals in La Pine/Bend.

name: Hood To Coast Relay
hook: The world’s largest 196-mile sunset-to-finish relay from mountain to sea.
description: The iconic Hood To Coast sends teams of 8–12 runners from Mount Hood across Oregon into the Pacific. Van relay logistics, mountain and scenic terrain, and festival at the finish make it a bucket-list race.
venue: Mt. Hood National Forest to Seaside Beach
lodging: Hotels in Portland, Cascade Locks, Seaside; campsites along route book early.

name: Pine to Palm 100
hook: Remote Siskiyou singletrack with 20,000+ feet of vert and big views.
description: A rugged point‑to‑point through Southern Oregon’s Siskiyou Mountains with high, exposed ridges and stout climbs, finishing in downtown Ashland.
cost: Entry via UltraSignup; details vary annually
lodging: Motels in Grants Pass/Medford/Ashland; limited services along course.

name: Oil Creek 100 Trail Runs
hook: Rolling, rooty loops through Pennsylvania’s oil‑boom history.
description: Runners circle the Gerard Hiking Trail in Oil Creek State Park on 100M/100K/50K routes with aid at the historic Drake Well Museum. Fall foliage and slick roots add challenge.
cost: Tiered entry by distance
venue: Oil Creek State Park / Drake Well Museum
lodging: Local motels and park camping; book early for foliage season.

name: Chattajack 31
hook: 31 miles through the Tennessee River Gorge for SUPs and kayaks.
description: A point‑to‑point endurance paddle from downtown Chattanooga into the scenic Tennessee River Gorge, ending near Hale’s Bar with strict safety rules and checkpoints.
cost: Entry fee varies by craft; sells out quickly
lodging: Hotels downtown and lodges/rentals near the gorge and finish.

name: Chattajack 31
hook: 31 miles down the Tennessee River gorge for SUPs and kayaks.
description: A point‑to‑point endurance paddle from downtown Chattanooga through the Tennessee River Gorge to Hale’s Bar. Open to SUP, surfski, kayak, and OC craft with strict safety rules.
cost: Entry fee varies by craft; sells out quickly
lodging: Hotels in downtown Chattanooga and near the finish shuttle area.

name: Moonshiners PPG Fly‑In
hook: Paramotor gathering at Johnson County Airport in the Appalachians.
description: A popular powered‑paragliding meet with morning and evening flights, pilot briefings, and on‑site camping at 6A4 Johnson County Airport. Weather windows dictate flying each day.
cost: Pilot registration; spectators free
lodging: On‑site camping; hotels and rentals in Mountain City and nearby.

name: The Barkley Marathons
hook: Infamously brutal off-trail loops with secret start and scant mercy.
description: A limited-field ultramarathon of five off-trail loops totaling ~100 miles in Frozen Head State Park. Entry and exact dates are not publicly posted; tradition and difficulty define the event.
cost: Application process; entry details are not publicly posted
lodging: Motels in Wartburg/Rockwood; state park camping when available.

name: Sky Island — Davis Mountains
hook: High-desert switchbacks, Indian Lodge climb, and Davis Mountains big sky.
description: A rugged 25K/50K at Fort Davis with steep climbs, slick rock, and wide-open views. Starts at Prude Ranch and tags Davis Mountains State Park, including the famed Indian Lodge climb. Cooler fall temps and desert wind shape the day.
venue: Prude Ranch & Davis Mountains State Park
address: 201 Prude Guest Ranch Rd, Fort Davis, TX 79734
lodging: Lodging in Fort Davis and nearby Alpine; limited rooms—book early. Campgrounds at Davis Mountains SP.

name: Texas Water Safari
hook: 260 river miles to the Gulf—human-powered, nonstop, and notorious.
description: Billed as the “World’s Toughest Canoe Race,” this 260-mile challenge runs from San Marcos down the San Marcos and Guadalupe Rivers to Seadrift. Teams self-support with a designated land captain and face heat, tides, and night paddling.
cost: Standard entry; details and captain requirements on official site
venue: Kuhlbachers Gator Den (start vicinity) → Seadrift finish
lodging: Hotels in San Marcos and Victoria; coastal lodging near Seadrift. Crews stage along checkpoints.
ageRestriction: 13+ with adult in boat; 18+ for solo

name: Moab 240 Endurance Run
hook: A single-loop 240-mile odyssey through mesas, canyons, and mountains.
description: Destination Trail’s signature 200-plus features slickrock, desert canyons, two mountain ranges, and long, windy nights. A massive loop around Moab challenges sleep strategy, heat management, and navigation on marked backcountry routes.
cost: Tiered entry; details on official site
lodging: Hotels and rentals in Moab book early; BLM and park campgrounds in season.

name: The Bear 100
hook: Point‑to‑point from Utah to Idaho through the Bear River Range.
description: A classic mountain 100 finishing at Bear Lake. Runners traverse rugged climbs, changing weather, and high‑country trails on a route famed for fall colors.
cost: Lottery/entry via organizer; details posted annually
lodging: Hotels/rentals in Logan and Bear Lake towns; limited on‑course services.

name: Wasatch Front 100
hook: A classic Rocky Mountain point-to-point with big vert and wild weather.
description: The Wasatch Front 100 traverses the Wasatch Range from the foothills above Kaysville to Midway. Steep climbs, rugged footing, and rapidly shifting mountain weather define this lottery-entry classic.
cost: Entry fees and lottery details on official site
lodging: Hotels around Davis County, Park City, and Heber Valley; book early.

name: Blue Ridge Relay
hook: 200-mile relay across the mountains from the Highlands to Asheville in under 36 hours.
description: Teams of 7–12 run across the Blue Ridge Mountains over 36 hours beginning at Grayson Highlands State Park and finishing in Asheville. Vans advance support while runners enjoy ridgeline views and small-town aid.
lodging: Motels in Wytheville, Galax, Black Mountain and Asheville; some racers camp near the start.

name: Grindstone Trail Running Festival
hook: Shenandoah-side ridgelines with 100M/100K/50K/21K options at a festival-style venue.
description: UTMB World Series event based at Natural Chimneys Park with multiple distances. Expect humid Appalachian climbs, forest singletrack, and a lively expo scene centered at the park’s limestone towers.
cost: Standard UTMB-series pricing; see site
address: 94 Natural Chimneys Ln, Mt Solon, VA 22843
lodging: Campground at Natural Chimneys (reserve early); hotels in Staunton/Harrisonburg.

name: Massanutten Mountain Trails 100
hook: Rocky Shenandoah singletrack with 18,000+ feet of climbing.
description: A demanding loop through the Massanutten Mountains of Virginia with rocky footing, stout climbs, and a generous but real 36‑hour cutoff.
cost: Standard entry via organizer site/UltraSignup
lodging: Cabins and campgrounds in Fort Valley/Luray; limited local lodging.

name: Old Dominion 100
hook: Historic East Coast 100‑miler on roads and rugged mountain trails.
description: Founded in 1979, the OD100 mixes paved sections with tough Shenandoah mountain trails. A classic buckle‑earning challenge with deep roots.
cost: Entry via organizer; fees posted annually
lodging: Inns and rentals around Orkney Springs/Basye; limited on‑course services.

name: Vermont 100 Endurance Run
hook: Rolling Green Mountain dirt roads and trails with deep community roots.
description: One of the country’s oldest 100‑milers. Runners traverse dirt roads, farm lanes, and wooded trails with significant climbing around Silver Hill Meadow.
cost: Lottery/entry via organizers; benefits Vermont Adaptive
lodging: Area inns and rentals; on‑site camping typically available for participants.

name: Vermont 50 (Run & MTB)
hook: Classic 50‑mile run and mountain‑bike race on Ascutney’s trails and roads.
description: A fundraiser for Vermont Adaptive featuring a 50‑mile MTB race plus 50‑mile/50K runs across dirt roads, jeep track, and woodland trails in West Windsor.
cost: Tiered entry; benefits Vermont Adaptive
lodging: Inns and rentals around Brownsville/Woodstock; limited camping options.

name: Bigfoot 200
hook: A 200-mile traverse of St. Helens backcountry, lava fields, and deep forest.
description: A remote, fully marked 200.1-mile route circling Mount St. Helens and the Goat Rocks. Sleep stations, massive elevation change, and long stretches of wilderness define Destination Trail’s Pacific Northwest epic.
cost: Tiered entry; see lottery and manual
lodging: Limited lodging in Randle/Morton; forest campgrounds and Sno-Parks along the course.

name: Cascade Crest 100
hook: Technical Pacific Northwest singletrack with tunnels, ridges, and roots.
description: A demanding loop from Easton through the Cascades featuring rugged trails, the historic Snoqualmie Tunnel, and classic PNW weather. Entry typically via lottery.
cost: Lottery/entry via organizer; fees posted annually
lodging: Lodging in Cle Elum/Ellensburg; camping options near Easton.

name: Plain 100
hook: Unmarked, self-supported 100 on rugged loops—navigation and grit required.
description: A famously spartan event with no course markings and no aid stations. Runners tackle remote loops near Plain, Washington, carrying everything they need and relying on map-and-compass savvy.
cost: Standard entry; strict requirements published
lodging: Small-town lodging around Plain and Leavenworth; dispersed camping in national forest.

name: AAC Craggin’ Classic – New River Gorge
hook: Workshops and clinics on the sandstone cliffs of the New River Gorge.
description: The American Alpine Club’s traveling festival stops at the New River Gorge with clinics, stewardship projects, and nightly programming for climbers.
cost: Festival tickets and clinic fees
venue: New River Gorge National Park and Preserve
lodging: Campgrounds and cabins around Fayetteville; national park camping nearby.

name: Bridge Day (New River Gorge)
hook: One day a year the bridge opens for legal BASE jumps into the gorge.
description: West Virginia’s largest single-day festival closes the New River Gorge Bridge for BASE jumps, rappels, and a full day of viewing. Vendors line the span and rim; tandem BASE is limited and books out fast.
cost: Spectating free; specialty activities ticketed
lodging: Hotels and rentals in Fayetteville/Summersville; campground options in the national park.

name: Bighorn Trail Run
hook: Wildflower singletrack, creek crossings, and big vert on Wyoming’s North Shore.
description: The Bighorn 100, 52, 32, and 18 mile races traverse the Tongue River region with steep forest climbs, river canyon descents, and unpredictable spring weather. A longtime community event anchored out of Dayton and Sheridan.
cost: Standard entry; details on official site
venue: Tongue River Canyon / Scott Park (finish area)
lodging: Hotels in Sheridan/Dayton; camping options in Bighorn National Forest.
